history.content: I heard that changing your grad year could backfire bc you'd be a junior in their system and applying again as a junior the next year would be sus

children.subject: If it's a big company with lots of interns, they're more easily predictable--if it's been a while (a couple months, say, after you applied or something like a month after the day they said they'd get back to you), then it's probably a no-go. Smaller companies and startups are not really predictable, I've had a company which took only a few interns every year respond after like 2 months of silence and I eventually got the internship. Sometimes, because there's so few positions, they respond almost immediately. But since you are probably thinking mostly about your apps to  the big companies anyway, I'd say if it's been a while then they probably took someone else (though sometimes interns do weasel out after accepting an offer, in which case it's still possible you're being considered!).

history.content:
Hi, I'm a second year CS major and I applied to 100+ companies a week ago, and have only gotten rejection letters from around 10 of them. I know that a lot of companies won't reply if they reject you, so I just want to know how long do I need to wait until I can be sure that I'm rejected by all of these companies? 

Also, I heard saying myself is junior is very useful. Is it acceptable to write my expected graduation year one year ahead to make me look like a junior? (I have senior standing on Calcentral but I heard that doesn't mean anything)
history.subject: How long does it take before a company rejects you?
